content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Laura Sullivan: Well, I was born in Portland, Oregon, and I've always felt a deep connection to the Pacific Northwest. My parents were both well-educated—my father had a graduate degree in engineering, and my mother has a bachelor's in education. We lived in a small neighborhood in the Pacific area when I was a kid, and though I moved to a different city in Oregon when I turned 16, I've always considered myself a Portlander at heart. Growing up, I was pretty sheltered but also had a lot of opportunities because my family was financially stable. I went to college on a part-time basis while working, which was tough, but I managed to earn my bachelor's degree in social work. I've always been drawn to helping others, which is why I ended up in my current job, even though I work part-time now. I'm married to a wonderful man who's also very involved in community work, and we have two kids. Life hasn't been without its challenges, but I've always tried to stay grounded in my faith and my values.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Laura Sullivan: Yes, there was a moment that really shaped who I am. I was in my early twenties, working full-time at a nonprofit while going to school part-time. I had the chance to take a job offer in Seattle that would have paid significantly more and offered more stability, but it was in a corporate setting that didn't align with my values. At the same time, I was volunteering with a local community center that focused on supporting low-income families, and I felt a deep calling to continue that work. I remember sitting with my husband one night, weighing the pros and cons of each path. He encouraged me to follow my heart, even if it meant less financial security. I chose to stay in the nonprofit sector, and while it was harder financially, it gave me a sense of purpose that I couldn't have gotten anywhere else. That decision solidified my commitment to social work and to living a life that reflects my faith and my belief in helping others. It wasn't an easy choice, but it was the right one for me.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Laura Sullivan: I think it was a conscious choice, but not one I made in a single moment. It was more of a gradual realization, like a path unfolding over time. I had always been drawn to helping others, even as a child—whether it was babysitting for neighbors or organizing food drives at my church. But when I was in my early twenties, I started to understand that my values weren't just about being kind or doing good deeds; they were about dedicating my life to a cause that mattered. I didn't just 'choose' to stay in the nonprofit sector—I felt it was where I was meant to be. It wasn't always easy, and there were times when I questioned if I was making the right decision, but I think the difference was that I was actively choosing to align my life with what I believed in, rather than letting external pressures or convenience dictate my path.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Laura Sullivan: Absolutely, I think having support from others made all the difference. My husband was my biggest advocate during that time—he reminded me of why I started this journey in the first place. Also, my mentor at the community center, a woman named Margaret, was someone I looked up to. She had been in the nonprofit world for decades and had faced similar challenges. She shared her own story with me, which helped me realize that staying true to my values wasn't just a choice—it was a responsibility. I also leaned on my faith; my parish priest was someone I could talk to openly about my doubts and fears. He didn't push me toward one path or another, but he reminded me that God calls people to different things, and sometimes the hardest path is the one that leads to the most meaningful work. I don't think I could have made that decision without the people who believed in me and encouraged me to listen to my heart.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Laura Sullivan: Yes, I'm married to a wonderful man named Daniel. We met in college, actually—though I was working part-time and going to school, he was a full-time student majoring in environmental science. We bonded over our shared love for community service and our commitment to making a difference in the world. We got married a few years after I graduated, and we've been together ever since. We have two kids: a daughter, Emily, who's 8, and a son, Michael, who's 5. Both of them are incredibly curious and compassionate, just like their parents. Raising them has been one of the greatest joys of my life, though it's also come with its own set of challenges. I try to instill in them the same values that were important to me growing up—kindness, faith, and the importance of helping others. Daniel and I both work in community-focused roles, so our kids are used to seeing us involved in volunteer work and local initiatives. It's not always easy balancing work and family, especially with part-time jobs and the demands of raising two kids, but we make it work. Our family is our priority, and I wouldn't trade this life for anything.

Going through the interview questions reminded me of how much my life has been shaped by the values I hold dear—helping others, staying true to my faith, and being part of a supportive community. It also made me reflect on the pivotal moment in my early twenties when I chose to stay in the nonprofit sector rather than take a more financially stable corporate job. That decision wasn't made in a single moment but was the result of a gradual realization that my purpose lies in serving others. I'm grateful for the people who supported me along the way—my husband, my mentor, and my faith community—because without their encouragement, I might not have had the courage to follow my heart. Now, as a mother of two, I see those same values reflected in my children, and it gives me hope for the future. It's amazing how the stories we tell about our lives can help us understand who we are and where we're headed.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Laura Sullivan: My immediate family includes my parents, Richard and Anna, who still live in the same small town in Oregon where I grew up. They've always been a source of love and support, even though we don't see each other as often as I'd like. My father, Richard, is retired now but was a professor of engineering at a local university before he retired. He's always been very proud of my career choices, even though he sometimes worries about the financial stability of working in the nonprofit sector. My mother, Anna, is still active in her community—she volunteers at the same church I grew up in and has taken on a leadership role in the women's group there. She's been a huge influence on me, not just because of her education but because of her unwavering faith and compassion. I also have an older brother, Thomas, who lives in Seattle. He's a teacher, and we don't always see eye to eye politically, but we have a strong bond. We talk often, and even though we disagree on some issues, I respect his perspective. Family has always been important to me, and I'm grateful for the relationships I've had with each of them, even when life has taken us in different directions.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Laura Sullivan: Of course, there are many people outside of my family who have been important to me. One person who comes to mind is Margaret, my mentor at the community center I worked at in my early twenties. She was like a second mother to me, offering both guidance and tough love when I needed it most. Her belief in me helped me stay the course when I was tempted to take the corporate job in Seattle. Then there's my best friend, Sarah, who I met in college. We've been through a lot together—late-night study sessions, parenting struggles, and even some personal crises. She's the one I call when I need to vent or just be reminded of why I started this journey in the first place. I also have a small group of friends from my church who meet regularly for coffee and prayer. They're not just friends—they're part of my spiritual family. I wouldn't be where I am today without the support of these people, and I try to pay it forward by being there for others in the same way they've been there for me.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Laura Sullivan: I live in a quiet neighborhood just a few blocks from the river, in a cozy house with a small garden that my kids love to play in. It's a tight-knit community where people know each other, and there's always someone willing to lend a hand. We have a local park nearby where we often take the kids, and there's a community center that hosts events like food drives, art classes, and even weekly prayer groups. I've always appreciated the sense of belonging here, and it's one of the reasons I chose to stay in Portland after college. Even though I work part-time, I find that the slower pace of life in this neighborhood allows me to be more present for my family and my work. There's a lot of diversity in the area too—people from different backgrounds, cultures, and walks of life, which I think is really important for raising kids who are open-minded and compassionate. I feel lucky to be part of this community, and I try to give back whenever I can, whether it's through volunteering or just being a friendly neighbor.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Laura Sullivan: I feel very safe here, which is something I didn't take for granted growing up. My parents always emphasized the importance of community and looking out for one another, and I think that's something that's still alive in this neighborhood. There's a sense of mutual respect and care that I don't see in every place. I've never had to worry about walking alone at night or leaving my doors unlocked, which is something I'm grateful for. It also helps that the local police department is very responsive, and there are neighborhood watch programs that keep things peaceful. I think safety is more than just the absence of crime—it's about feeling connected to the people around you, knowing that if something happens, someone will be there to help. That's definitely the case here, and it makes all the difference in the world.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Laura Sullivan: Living here has been mostly positive, but like anywhere, there are challenges. One of the things I love most is the sense of community—it's rare to find a place where people genuinely care about one another. That said, the slower pace of life can sometimes feel overwhelming when I'm juggling work, family, and volunteer commitments. There are days when I feel stretched thin, especially when the kids are sick or when a project at the community center takes up more time than I anticipated. But I also find that the support system here helps me push through. Whether it's a neighbor who offers to watch the kids while I run errands or a friend who checks in when I'm feeling overwhelmed, I'm reminded that no one has to go through life alone. I think the key to making this place work for me is balance—knowing when to say yes to helping others and when to prioritize my own well-being. It's not always easy, but I wouldn't trade this neighborhood for anything. It's home.

Going through the questions about my family and neighborhood reminded me of how deeply connected I am to the people and places that shape my life. Talking about my husband, children, and parents brought up so many memories of love, support, and the values we've passed down through generations. It also made me reflect on how lucky I am to live in a neighborhood where people truly care for one another. It's not just about the safety or the convenience—it's about the sense of belonging and the knowledge that I'm part of something bigger. I think these conversations helped me realize how much my life has been built on relationships, community, and the belief that we're all in this together.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Laura Sullivan: A typical week for me is pretty balanced between work, family, and community involvement, though it varies depending on the season and what's going on with the kids. On weekdays, I usually wake up early, around 6:30 or 7, to get the kids ready for school and have a quiet moment with my coffee before the day starts. I work part-time at the community center, so my days are usually from 9 to 12, and then I pick the kids up from school. After that, I spend the afternoon helping with homework, playing with them, or running errands. I also try to fit in some time for myself—whether it's reading, going for a walk, or just sitting in the garden with a cup of tea. On weekends, we usually have family time—maybe a trip to the park, a visit to my parents, or a simple day at home with a movie and some board games. I also volunteer a few hours each week at the food bank or the local church, which keeps me connected to the community. It's not always perfect, and there are definitely days when I feel like I'm juggling too many things at once, but I try to remind myself that this rhythm is what makes life meaningful for me. I think the key is that I'm not just going through the motions—I'm living with intention, even if it's not always easy.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Laura Sullivan: I work part-time at a local community center, where I help coordinate programs for low-income families, including after-school activities for kids, food distribution, and job readiness workshops. My hours are typically from 9 a.m. to 12 p.m., Monday through Friday, which allows me to be home with my kids in the afternoons. I also volunteer a few hours each week at the food bank and the church, so my schedule can sometimes shift depending on what's needed. While it's not the highest-paying job, it's one that gives me purpose and allows me to stay connected to the people and causes I care about most. I've always believed that work should be more than just a paycheck—it should be a way to contribute to something bigger than yourself. That's why I chose this path, even when it meant sacrificing some financial stability. I know I'm not in it for the money, and that's okay. What matters is that I'm doing what I was meant to do.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Laura Sullivan: Yes, there are a few other routines and responsibilities that I haven't mentioned. One of them is my daily prayer time, which I try to keep consistent even when life gets busy. I find that starting the day with a few minutes of quiet reflection helps me center myself and remember why I'm here. I also have a habit of journaling, especially when I'm feeling overwhelmed or trying to process something important. It's a way for me to sort through my thoughts and stay grounded in my values. Another thing I do is cook meals in advance on weekends so that I can have something healthy and comforting ready for the week. It's a small act, but it helps me feel more in control of my time and reduces the stress of daily meal planning. I also make it a point to read a little each night, whether it's a novel or something related to my work. It's not always easy to find time for all of these things, but I believe that these small routines help me stay balanced and connected to what matters most in life.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Laura Sullivan: One recent change to my daily routine has been incorporating more mindfulness practices into my mornings. I started doing short guided meditations while my kids are getting ready for school, which has helped me stay more present and less stressed. I also began taking a 15-minute walk with my daughter before she heads off to school, which has been a nice way to bond and start the day with fresh energy. It's amazing how small adjustments can make such a big difference in how I feel throughout the day. I think these changes have helped me be more patient with myself and with my family, especially during the busier times. It's not about perfection—it's about finding little ways to care for myself so I can show up better for the people I love.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Laura Sullivan: During the school year, my kids have a pretty structured routine. They wake up around 7:30 a.m., have breakfast, and then get ready for school. Emily, my daughter, is in third grade, and she has a full day at school, while Michael, my son, is in kindergarten and has a shorter day. After school, Emily usually has an after-school program at the community center where she does homework, plays with other kids, and sometimes participates in art or music activities. Michael is picked up a little earlier, and he usually has some time to play outside before we head home. Once we're back, we have a light snack and then it's homework time—though Michael's homework is pretty minimal. In the evenings, we try to have dinner together as a family, and then we often read a story or play a game. On some days, Emily has a club or activity after school, like a science club or a drama group, which keeps her engaged and busy. I think having these routines helps them feel secure and gives them a sense of structure, which is especially important for kids their age. It also gives me some time to catch up on work or relax a bit before the day is over.

Going through the interview questions about my family, neighborhood, and daily routines has made me reflect on how deeply connected I am to the people and places that shape my life. It reminded me of the importance of community, not just in the sense of safety or convenience, but in the way it fosters belonging and support. Talking about my husband, children, and parents brought up so many memories of love, support, and the values we've passed down through generations. It also made me appreciate how lucky I am to live in a neighborhood where people truly care for one another. I think these conversations helped me realize how much my life has been built on relationships, community, and the belief that we're all in this together. It also made me think about my daily routines—how even small things like morning prayers, journaling, and meal prep help me stay grounded and connected to what matters most. I'm grateful for the balance I've found in my life, even when it's not perfect, and I feel more intentional about the choices I make every day.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Laura Sullivan: In terms of my health, I'd say I'm generally in pretty good shape, though I wouldn't call myself athletic. I try to stay active by walking with the kids most days and doing some light yoga in the evenings when I have the time. I do have some chronic issues, like mild arthritis in my knees from years of walking and standing during my work at the community center, but I manage it with regular stretching and over-the-counter pain relievers when needed. I also have a history of anxiety, which I've learned to manage through prayer, journaling, and talking to friends or my priest when I feel overwhelmed. I make sure to eat a balanced diet, mostly home-cooked meals, and I try to get enough sleep, though it's not always easy with two young kids. I think the biggest thing is that I've come to accept that my health is something I have to tend to regularly, just like any other part of my life. I don't take it for granted, and I'm grateful for the small things—like being able to run after my kids without too much pain or being able to stay up late reading when I need to unwind.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Laura Sullivan: What makes it easy to stay healthy for me is the support system I have in place—my family, friends, and faith community all remind me to take care of myself, even when life gets busy. My husband, Daniel, is always encouraging me to rest when I need to, and my kids remind me to move my body when they're running around the house. The hardest part, though, is finding time for myself when there are so many demands on my day. There are days when I feel guilty for taking a moment to breathe or stretch, thinking I should be doing something more 'productive.' But I've come to realize that taking care of my health isn't a luxury—it's a necessity. Without it, I can't be the best version of myself for my family or my work. I've started setting small reminders on my phone to take short breaks, drink water, or do a few minutes of deep breathing. It's not perfect, but it's a start, and I'm learning to be kinder to myself in the process.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Laura Sullivan: In the past two years, I've had a few health challenges that reminded me how important it is to take care of myself. The biggest thing was a flare-up of my knee arthritis last winter, which made it really hard to keep up with the kids and do my job at the community center. I had to take a few weeks off work to rest and see a physical therapist, which was tough because I felt like I was letting everyone down. But honestly, it was a wake-up call. I started incorporating more low-impact exercises, like swimming and gentle yoga, which have helped a lot. I also had a minor anxiety flare-up during the pandemic surge, which I managed with more frequent check-ins with my priest and some regular therapy sessions. It was a difficult time, but it taught me that it's okay to ask for help and that my mental health is just as important as my physical health. I've learned to be more proactive about scheduling time for rest and self-care, even if it's just a few minutes of deep breathing or a walk in the garden. These experiences have made me more compassionate with myself and more aware of how deeply connected my health is to my overall well-being.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Laura Sullivan: Yes, there were definitely times when my health challenges made things more difficult, especially when I was dealing with the knee flare-up last winter. I remember one day when I was trying to help Michael with his homework while also getting Emily ready for an after-school activity, and I just collapsed on the couch in pain. It was humbling to realize how much I relied on my body to keep up with the demands of work and family. I had to ask Daniel to take over some of the responsibilities for a while, and I felt guilty about it. But in the end, I think it taught me that asking for help isn't a weakness—it's a sign of strength. I also had to adjust how I approached my work at the community center, delegating more tasks and setting clearer boundaries so I could take the time I needed to recover. It wasn't easy, but it helped me realize that I can't pour from an empty cup. Taking care of my health isn't just about being able to work or care for my kids—it's about being present for them, even if that means slowing down and asking for support when I need it.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Laura Sullivan: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of emotions—some days I've felt deeply grateful for the life I have, and other days I've felt overwhelmed by the weight of it all. There were moments when I questioned whether I was doing enough, whether I was giving my kids the best possible life, or whether I was making a difference in the community I care so much about. But there were also moments of profound joy—like when Emily won a science fair at school or when Michael learned to ride his bike for the first time. Those little victories reminded me why I keep going. I've also been working on being more present in the moment, which has helped me feel more grounded. I've started setting aside time each evening to just sit with my kids and listen to them talk about their day, without distractions. It's not always easy, especially with the demands of work and the occasional health setback, but I'm learning to be more patient with myself and with the pace of life. I think the past year has been a journey of balance—trying to hold on to what matters most while also being okay with the imperfections of everyday life.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my daily routines and health have shaped my sense of balance and purpose. It reminded me that even small changes, like adding mindfulness practices or taking short walks with my daughter, can have a meaningful impact on how I feel throughout the day. It also made me think about how my health—both physical and mental—is not just something I need to manage, but something that directly affects my ability to show up for my family, my work, and my community. I've come to see that taking care of myself isn't selfish; it's necessary. The challenges I've faced, like the knee flare-up and anxiety flare during the pandemic, were hard, but they also taught me the importance of asking for help and setting boundaries. I'm learning that health isn't just about avoiding illness—it's about showing up with energy, presence, and compassion for myself and others. I'm grateful for the support I have, and I'm trying to be kinder to myself as I continue this journey of balance and self-care.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Laura Sullivan: I think I've struggled with anxiety from time to time, especially during the pandemic when everything felt so uncertain. There were days when I felt like I was constantly on edge, worrying about my kids, my job, and the state of the world. I didn't always recognize it as anxiety at first—I just thought I was being overwhelmed by life. But over time, I realized that I needed to take it more seriously. I started talking to my priest more regularly, and I also began seeing a therapist once a month. It's been a process, but it's helped me understand that anxiety doesn't define me, and that it's okay to reach out for help. I've also found that my faith has been a huge source of comfort. When I feel anxious, I try to remind myself that God is with me, and that I'm not alone in this. I'm still learning how to manage it, but I'm grateful for the tools I've gained along the way. I think the most important thing is that I'm no longer afraid to acknowledge when I'm struggling, and that I'm willing to do what it takes to take care of myself—whether that's through prayer, therapy, or just taking a few deep breaths when I need to.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Laura Sullivan: For my family, it's been a year of navigating challenges together, but also finding strength in our shared values. Daniel has been my rock, especially during the times when my anxiety felt overwhelming. He's always been there to remind me that we're in this together, and that our kids are watching how we handle stress and uncertainty. Emily and Michael have been resilient in their own ways—Emily has taken on more responsibility at home, like helping with simple chores, and Michael has become more independent, which is both heartwarming and a bit bittersweet. I think the pandemic really brought us closer as a family, even though it was a difficult time. We learned to adapt, to be flexible, and to find joy in the little things. There were moments when I worried about how the stress of it all might affect them, but I've seen how their curiosity and compassion have only grown. I'm grateful for the way we've supported each other through it all, and I know that whatever comes next, we'll face it together.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Laura Sullivan: For me, religion has always been a cornerstone of my life, shaping not only how I see the world but also how I navigate the challenges that come with it. Being Catholic, I find comfort in the rituals, the prayers, and the sense of community that comes with attending Mass every Sunday. It's more than just a tradition—it's a way of grounding myself in something bigger than myself. My faith has been especially important during difficult times, like when I was struggling with anxiety or when I had to make tough decisions about my career. It's given me a sense of purpose and reminded me that I'm not alone in this journey. I also find that my faith influences how I raise my children, teaching them about compassion, forgiveness, and the importance of helping others. Even when I don't have all the answers, I know that my faith is a source of strength and that it helps me stay connected to the values that matter most in life.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Laura Sullivan: To be honest, I don't use social media very often. I find that it can be a bit overwhelming with all the noise and comparisons, and I prefer to stay connected in more meaningful ways. I do use Facebook occasionally to keep in touch with family and old friends, especially my parents and my brother, who don't use other platforms as much. I also follow a few community groups and local nonprofits to stay informed about events and initiatives that align with my values. Instagram, on the other hand, just feels too fast-paced for me—I prefer to take time to reflect rather than scroll through endless content. I think it's important to be present in the real world, especially with my kids, and I try to limit screen time for them as well. That said, I do appreciate the way social media can bring people together for good causes, and I've participated in a few online fundraisers or awareness campaigns when I felt called to do so. For me, it's all about balance—using technology in a way that supports my life, rather than letting it take over.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Laura Sullivan: Honestly, I haven't relied much on social media for emotional or financial support, but I can see how it might help others. For me, my support has always come from the people I know in real life—my husband, my faith community, and the friends I've built relationships with over the years. That said, I have used Facebook a few times to reach out to people in my community when I needed help organizing a local event or when I wanted to share a story about our work at the community center. It's not the same as talking to someone face-to-face, but it can be a useful tool when you're trying to connect with others who share your values. I think the key is knowing when to use it and when to step away. I'm grateful for the support I've received in person, and I try to give back in the same way—whether through my work, my family, or my faith.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect deeply on how my health and emotional well-being have shaped the past year of my life. It reminded me that even though I've faced challenges like knee flare-ups and anxiety, these experiences have taught me the importance of self-compassion and asking for help when needed. I've come to understand that my health isn't just about physical strength—it's about being present for my family, my work, and my community. The past year has been a journey of learning to balance the demands of life with the need to care for myself, and I'm grateful for the support of my husband, my faith, and the people around me who remind me that I'm not alone in this. I've also realized that it's okay to struggle, and that acknowledging my feelings—whether through prayer, therapy, or simply talking to someone—can be a powerful step toward healing. These reflections have helped me see that my well-being is not a weakness, but a foundation for living a meaningful life.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Laura Sullivan: In the past year, I've noticed that my stress levels have fluctuated, but overall, I feel more equipped to handle them than I did before. There were times when I felt overwhelmed, especially when juggling work, family, and my own health challenges, but I've been more intentional about how I respond to those feelings. I've started incorporating more mindfulness into my daily routine, like taking a few deep breaths before responding to a difficult situation or pausing to reflect before making a decision. I've also found that talking through my worries with Daniel or my priest has been incredibly helpful. I used to try to handle everything on my own, but I've learned that it's okay to lean on others. I've also been more consistent with my prayer time and journaling, which helps me process my emotions and stay grounded. I think the biggest change is that I'm no longer afraid to acknowledge when I'm struggling—I see it as a sign that I need to slow down, not that I'm failing. It's a work in progress, but I feel more at peace with myself and my circumstances than I have in a long time.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Laura Sullivan: Last month, our biggest expenses were related to our kids' school supplies, extracurricular activities, and healthcare. Emily is in third grade, and she's involved in a few clubs, like the science club and drama group, which have some fees. Michael is in kindergarten, and while his activities are fewer, we still have some costs for his school supplies and a few enrichment programs. Healthcare was also a significant expense, especially with my knee therapy and the occasional prescriptions I need for my arthritis. We also have our regular monthly bills—rent, utilities, groceries, and car payments. I work part-time, and Daniel works in environmental consulting, so his income helps cover the majority of our expenses. We also rely on some community resources, like the food bank, to stretch our budget when needed. It's not always easy, but we've learned to be intentional with our spending, prioritizing what truly matters—like our kids' education, our health, and our ability to give back to the community. I think the key is that we're not extravagant, but we also make sure we're meeting our basic needs and supporting the causes we care about.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Laura Sullivan: Last month, our household spent around $3,200, which is actually a bit higher than usual. The increase was mainly due to Emily's science club membership and a special field trip fee, as well as some unexpected medical costs related to my knee therapy. Normally, we spend between $2,800 and $3,000 a month, with the majority going toward rent, groceries, and our kids' school-related expenses. Daniel's salary covers most of our bills, and I contribute what I can from my part-time job at the community center. We also rely on some community support, like the food bank, to help with groceries when needed. It's not always easy to stretch our budget, but we've learned to prioritize what's most important—our children's education, our health, and our ability to give back to the people around us. I think the key is being intentional with every dollar, even if it means making some sacrifices along the way.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Laura Sullivan: We rent our home, actually. It's a small two-bedroom apartment that's just the right size for our family of four. Rent is one of our biggest fixed costs, and while it's not cheap, it's manageable because Daniel's job in environmental consulting provides a steady income. We chose to rent rather than buy because I wanted more flexibility, especially with my part-time work and the possibility of needing to adjust our living situation if our family dynamics change in the future. Plus, renting allows us to stay in this neighborhood, which feels like home to me. I love the sense of community here, and I don't want to move away from that just for the sake of owning a house. It's not ideal for everyone, but for us, it's worked out well so far.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Laura Sullivan: Over the past year, our bills have definitely fluctuated with the seasons and life events. For example, during the winter months, our heating bill went up significantly, which was a bit of a strain on the budget. We also had higher grocery costs during the holidays, especially when we hosted our extended family for Christmas. School-related expenses also vary—when the kids are in full-time school, we have more fees for clubs, uniforms, and supplies, but during summer, those costs drop. Then there's the unpredictable stuff, like when I had to pay for my knee therapy or when Daniel had to cover unexpected car repairs. We've learned to budget for the big things, like school supplies and healthcare, but the smaller, unexpected costs can still catch us off guard. I think the biggest lesson has been flexibility—being able to adjust our spending when needed and relying on our community when things get tight. It's not always perfect, but we've found ways to make it work without sacrificing what's most important.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how deeply my family and faith have supported me through the challenges of the past year. It reminded me that even in times of stress and uncertainty, I'm not alone—my husband, my children, and my faith community have been constants in my life. I also thought about how I use social media, or rather, how I choose not to use it much, and how that decision aligns with my values of being present in the real world, especially with my kids. It's comforting to know that I don't need to rely on online connections for emotional support, because I already have a strong network of people who care about me in person. These reflections helped me appreciate the balance I've found in my life and the ways I've learned to prioritize what truly matters—family, faith, and community.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Laura Sullivan: I do have a savings account, though it's not as substantial as I'd like it to be. I try to set aside a small portion of my paycheck each month, even if it's just a few hundred dollars, to build a buffer for unexpected expenses. It's not always easy when we're juggling rent, groceries, and the kids' activities, but I've learned that even small amounts add up over time. I also have a separate jar at home where I put aside cash for little things—like school supplies or a special treat for the kids. It's more of a personal savings habit, and it helps me feel more in control of our finances, even when life throws us a curveball. I know I could be doing more, but I'm trying to be realistic about what's possible given our income and the needs of our family. At the end of the day, I'm grateful for what we have, and I'm working toward a future where we can save more and feel even more secure.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Laura Sullivan: In the last year, I've been saving more for a rainy day than for big purchases like a home. Honestly, buying a house feels a bit out of reach right now, given our income and the current market. Instead, I've been focusing on building an emergency fund so that if something unexpected happens—like a medical bill or a sudden repair—we don't have to scramble. I also try to save a little for the kids' future, like setting aside money for their college funds or extracurricular activities. It's not a lot, but it's something. I think the most important thing is that we're not living paycheck to paycheck, and that we have a little cushion to fall back on when life gets tough. It's not perfect, but it gives me peace of mind knowing that we're preparing for the future, even if it's just in small ways.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Laura Sullivan: My occupation has been in the nonprofit sector, specifically working with a local community center where I help coordinate programs for low-income families. My most important duties include organizing after-school activities for kids, managing food distribution programs, and facilitating job readiness workshops. I also work closely with volunteers and local organizations to ensure that the services we offer are accessible and meet the needs of the people we serve. What I find most rewarding about this work is the direct impact it has on people's lives—whether it's helping a single parent find employment, providing a safe space for kids to learn and grow, or simply offering a meal to someone in need. It's not always easy, and there are days when I feel like I'm barely keeping up with the demands, but I know that what I do matters. It's a calling, really, and one that I'm deeply committed to, even if it doesn't always come with the financial rewards that other careers might offer. I've always believed that work should be more than just a job—it should be a way to contribute to something bigger than yourself, and for me, that's exactly what this is.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Laura Sullivan: I usually work around 15 to 20 hours a week, depending on the time of year and what's going on with the community center. During the school year, I'm more consistently scheduled from 9 a.m. to 12 p.m., Monday through Friday, which allows me to be home with my kids in the afternoons. But during the summer, when we have more programs and events, my hours can stretch a bit longer, sometimes into the late afternoons. I also volunteer a few hours each week at the food bank and the church, so my schedule can vary a bit. It's not always easy balancing work with family and community responsibilities, but I've learned to be flexible and prioritize what matters most. I think the part-time schedule works well for us—it gives me the opportunity to be present for my kids and my work without feeling completely overwhelmed. I'm grateful for the flexibility, even if it means I don't always have the same level of financial security as some of my friends who work full-time.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Laura Sullivan: I didn't have more than one job in the traditional sense, but I did take on a few different roles that helped support our family in various ways. In addition to my part-time work at the community center, I also volunteered regularly at the food bank and the church, which, while not paid, were important ways to contribute to our community and stay connected to my values. I also helped out with occasional weekend events at the community center, like fundraisers or family workshops, which sometimes extended my hours beyond the usual 9 to 12 schedule. I also did some freelance writing for local nonprofits, mostly on a contract basis, which gave me a little extra income and kept me engaged with the causes I care about. It wasn't always easy juggling all of these things, especially with two young kids, but I found that having multiple roles—whether paid or unpaid—helped me feel more purposeful and connected to the people and work I care about. It wasn't about having more money; it was about making sure that every part of my life, even the unpaid ones, aligned with who I am and what I believe in.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how my stress levels and emotional coping strategies have evolved over the past year, and how my financial situation and household management play a role in my overall well-being. It reminded me that while life has its ups and downs, I've become more intentional about how I handle stress—whether through mindfulness, prayer, or simply talking to someone I trust. I also thought about how our household budget, though not extravagant, requires careful planning and flexibility, especially with the costs of raising two kids and managing my health. It's comforting to know that even with financial challenges, we've found ways to prioritize what matters most—our family, our health, and our community. These reflections helped me appreciate the balance I've found in my life and the ways I've learned to adapt, even when things don't always go as planned.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Laura Sullivan: In total, our household made around $4,500 in the past month. That includes Daniel's salary from his environmental consulting job, my part-time income from the community center, and the occasional freelance writing gigs I take on. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover our basic needs and some of the extras we value—like our kids' activities, our groceries, and our healthcare. I know it's not the same as what some of my friends earn, but I've learned to be content with what we have. What matters most is that we're able to live with purpose, support each other, and give back to the community in our own way. I think the key is that we're not chasing wealth for its own sake—we're building a life that reflects our values, and that gives me a deep sense of fulfillment, even if it doesn't always look like the traditional American dream.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Laura Sullivan: I've been at my current job at the community center for about six years now, and it's been a journey of growth and deepening commitment. The benefits of the job aren't always the traditional ones you might expect—there's no health insurance or paid vacation in the way that corporate jobs offer, but what we do have is something just as valuable: a sense of purpose and a supportive team. We all know why we're here, and that makes the work feel meaningful even on the toughest days. The community center provides some basic health coverage through a local nonprofit network, and we have a few days of unpaid leave each year for personal or family needs, which we can use for things like medical appointments or mental health days. I also appreciate the flexibility—it's not a 9-to-5 job in the traditional sense, but it allows me to be there for my kids and still contribute to the community. I know it's not perfect, but I wouldn't trade this for a job that paid more but didn't align with my values. What matters most is that I'm doing work that reflects who I am and what I believe in, and that gives me a deep sense of fulfillment.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Laura Sullivan: My relationships at work are really what make this job special. I have a great relationship with my manager, Sarah, who's been with the community center for over a decade. She's not just a supervisor—she's like a mentor to me. She's always been supportive, even when I've had to make tough decisions, like when I chose to stay in the nonprofit sector instead of taking the corporate job in Seattle. She understood where I was coming from and encouraged me to follow my heart. As for my coworkers, we're all in this together. We're a diverse group of people—some are full-time, some part-time, and some volunteers—but we share a common goal: to make a difference in the lives of others. We have a lot of trust and respect for one another, and it shows in the way we collaborate. Whether it's helping each other with the heavy lifting during events or just having a laugh over coffee, I feel like I'm part of a family here. That kind of support is rare, and I'm really grateful for it.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Laura Sullivan: My work schedule is pretty predictable during the school year, which is good because it helps me balance everything else in my life. I usually work Monday through Friday from 9 a.m. to 12 p.m., and that gives me the afternoons to be with my kids, do some errands, or catch up on personal tasks. But things can get a bit more flexible during the summer, especially when we have special events or programs at the community center. Sometimes I'll work a few extra hours in the afternoons or even on weekends, depending on what's needed. I also have the freedom to adjust my hours a bit if something comes up at home, which is something I really appreciate. It's not always perfect—there are days when I have to work late or when I need to leave early for a family commitment—but overall, the flexibility is one of the things I love most about this job. It allows me to be present for my family while still contributing to the community in a meaningful way.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Laura Sullivan: Overall, I feel content with my financial situation, even if it's not what I would call stable or luxurious. We're not living paycheck to paycheck, and we have enough to cover our basic needs, our kids' education, and some of the things that make life meaningful to us—like community involvement and family time. I know it's not the same as what some of my friends have, especially those who work full-time in corporate jobs, but I've come to accept that my path is different. What matters most to me isn't the amount of money in the bank, but the sense of purpose that comes from doing work I believe in and being able to support my family in the way that feels right. I'm not without worries—there are definitely days when I think about how we might handle a sudden expense or if we'll be able to afford something unexpected. But I've learned to be grateful for what we have and to focus on the things that truly matter. I think the biggest thing is that I'm not chasing wealth for its own sake—I'm building a life that reflects my values, and that gives me a deep sense of fulfillment, even if it doesn't always look like the traditional American dream.

Going through the interview questions from 36 to 40 made me reflect on how my financial situation and work life are deeply intertwined with the values I hold most dear. It reminded me that while our household budget fluctuates with the seasons and unexpected expenses, we've found a way to live intentionally—prioritizing what truly matters, like our family, our health, and our community. I also thought about how my part-time job at the community center, along with my volunteer work and freelance writing, allows me to be present for my kids while still contributing to something bigger than myself. These reflections helped me appreciate the life I have and the choices I've made, even when they don't always align with what society might consider success.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Laura Sullivan: Yes, both my parents worked for pay while I was growing up, though their roles were quite different. My father was a professor of engineering at a local university, and he worked full-time throughout my childhood. He was always very dedicated to his work, but he also made sure to be present for our family—whether it was helping with homework or taking us on weekend trips. My mother, on the other hand, worked part-time as a teacher in a local school, and she also volunteered extensively in the community. She had a bachelor's degree in education, and she was passionate about making a difference in the lives of her students. Even though she worked part-time, she always emphasized the importance of education and service, which is something I carry with me today. I think their work experiences shaped the values I hold dear—my father's dedication to his profession and my mother's commitment to helping others. It's interesting how their paths, though different, both taught me the importance of hard work and purpose in life.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Laura Sullivan: My father's job was as a professor of engineering at a local university, and his most important activities involved teaching, conducting research, and mentoring students. He had a deep passion for his work, and I remember how excited he would get when he was working on new projects or helping students solve complex problems. He also made it a point to be involved in our family life, even with his busy schedule. My mother worked part-time as a teacher in a local elementary school, and her most important duties included planning lessons, grading assignments, and supporting her students both academically and emotionally. She had a way of making every child feel seen and valued, and I think that's why she was so beloved by her students and their families. What I remember most about both of their jobs was how they approached them with integrity and purpose. They didn't just show up for the paycheck—they showed up because they believed in what they were doing, and that taught me a lot about how to live my own life with the same kind of dedication and heart.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Laura Sullivan: My father worked for a local university, which was a public institution focused on engineering and the sciences. He was part of a faculty that taught both undergraduate and graduate students, and he also led research projects that often involved partnerships with local industries. His work was both academic and practical—he didn't just teach theory; he made sure students understood how engineering could solve real-world problems. My mother worked for a public elementary school in our town, which was part of the same school district I attended. She was a classroom teacher, but she also took on extra responsibilities, like organizing school events and mentoring new teachers. I remember her talking about how she loved the way teaching allowed her to make a direct impact on children's lives. Both of them worked in environments that valued education and service, and I think that's why I ended up choosing a career in social work and nonprofit work—it felt like a natural extension of the values they instilled in me growing up.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Laura Sullivan: If I imagine myself a few years from now, I hope I'm still living in this neighborhood, still surrounded by the people who make this community feel like home. I hope my kids are growing into compassionate, curious, and kind young adults—people who carry the values we've instilled in them and who are willing to stand up for what they believe in. I hope I'm still working at the community center, even if my role has evolved, and that I'm still finding ways to contribute to the lives of others. I also hope that I'm healthier, both physically and mentally, and that I'm better at balancing the demands of work, family, and self-care. I don't know exactly what the future will look like, but I do know that I want to continue living with purpose, staying true to my faith, and being present for the people I love. I hope that whatever comes next, it's filled with moments of joy, connection, and the quiet understanding that we're all in this together.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Laura Sullivan: What I value the most in my life is the sense of connection—whether it's with my family, my faith community, or the people I work with at the community center. I believe that no one should go through life alone, and I've been so blessed to have people who support me, encourage me, and remind me of my purpose. I value kindness, compassion, and the belief that we're all called to help one another in some way. I also value the small, everyday moments—the sound of my kids laughing, the quiet time I have in the garden, the way my husband still holds my hand when we're walking through the park. These things ground me and remind me that life isn't about grand achievements or wealth, but about love, presence, and the simple act of showing up for the people and causes that matter most. I think that's what gives my life meaning, and I hope I never lose sight of that.

These reflections helped me appreciate the life I have and the choices I've made, even when they don't always align with what society might consider success.
